query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato, 2 quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco 3 che da neun sentiero era segnato.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Nessus had not yet arrived on the other side, 2 when we set out through a wood 3 that was marked by no path.
**Old English:**
1 Nis ðæt Næssas flota ofer wæges stream, 2 ða we gesawon ðurh ðone wudugong, 3 ðæt ðær nænig stigol wæs gestaðelod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti 8 quelle fiere selvagge che ’n odio hanno 9 tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti.
query.result:
**English:**
7 They have not such rough thickets nor so dense 8 those savage beasts that hate 9 the cultivated places between Cecina and Corneto.
**Old English:**
7 Ne nabbað heo næfre swylce wudu wilde 8 ða wælhreowan deor ðe on ðam wudu eardiað 9 betwux Cecina and Corneto.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Quivi le brutte Arpie lor nidi fanno, 11 che cacciar de le Strofade i Troiani 12 con tristo annunzio di futuro danno.
query.result:
**English:**
10 There the foul Harpies make their nests, 11 who drove the Trojans from the Strophades 12 with sad tidings of future harm.
**Old English:**
10 Þær ða wælhreowean wigstede healdad, 11 ða ðe Troiana trymedon fram ðam Strophadon 12 mid hearme ðæs wælhreowan geleafan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Ali hanno late, e colli e visi umani, 14 piè con artigli, e pennuto ’l gran ventre; 15 fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani.
query.result:
**English:**
13 They have broad wings, and human necks and heads, 14 feet with claws, and their great bellies are feathered; 15 they make laments in the strange trees.
**Old English:**
13 Hæfdon brade fyðru, and næglas on handa, 14 and hals and heafod wæron mannes hiw, 15 feterum fæste, and feðrum beweaxen; 16 macodon hream on heah treowum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 E ’l buon maestro «Prima che più entre, 17 sappi che se’ nel secondo girone», 18 mi cominciò a dire, «e sarai mentre
19 che tu verrai ne l’orribil sabbione.
query.result:
**English:**
16 And the good master said, "Before you go any further, 17 know that you are in the second circle," 18 he began to say to me, "and you will be there until
19 you come to the horrible sand.
**Old English:**
16 And se goda lareow "Ær ðe ðu firre gange, 17 wite ðæt ðu eart on ðam oðrum ymbhwyrft," 18 ongan ða to secganne me, "and ðu bist ðær ða hwile
19 oð ðæt ðu cymst to ðam orrigenan sande.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
20 Però riguarda ben; sì vederai 21 cose che torrien fede al mio sermone».
22 Io sentia d’ogne parte trarre guai 23 e non vedea persona che ’l facesse; 24 per ch’io tutto smarrito m’arrestai.
query.result:
**English:**
20 Therefore look carefully; you will see 21 things that would make my words seem unbelievable.
22 I heard cries of pain from every side, 23 but I saw no one who was making them; 24 so I stopped, completely bewildered.
**Old English:**
20 Forðæm beheald wel; ðu gesyhst ða ðing 21 ðe minum wordum ungeleafful ðyncað.
22 Ic gehyrde of æghwylcum stede hrymgan 23 and ne geseah nænne ðe ða ræda worhte; 24 forðæm ic eall forht ðær stod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Cred’ ïo ch’ei credette ch’io credesse 26 che tante voci uscisser, tra quei bronchi, 27 da gente che per noi si nascondesse.
query.result:
**English:**
25 I believed that he believed that I believed 26 that so many voices came from among those branches, 27 from people who were hiding from us.
**Old English:**
25 Ic wende ðæt he wende ðæt ic wende 26 ðæt swa fela stemna comon, betwux ðam beorgum, 27 of folce ðe ðurh us wæron forholen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Però disse ’l maestro: «Se tu tronchi 29 qualche fraschetta d’una d’este piante, 30 li pensier c’hai si faran tutti monchi».
query.result:
**English:**
28 Therefore the master said: "If you break off 29 a small branch from one of these plants, 30 the thoughts that you have will all be broken."
**Old English:**
28 Þa cwæð se lareow: "Gif ðu brycst 29 ænige gyrde of ðissum treowum, 30 ða geþohtas þe ðu hæfst beoð ealle gebrocene."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Allor porsi la mano un poco avante 32 e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno; 33 e ’l tronco suo gridò: «Perché mi schiante?».
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then I stretched out my hand a little forward 32 and plucked a branch from a great thorn bush; 33 and its trunk cried out: “Why do you tear me?”
**Old English:**
31 Þa ic ða handa forð gesträhte 32 and of ðam miclan þorne nam a twyg; 33 and ða ðæs treowes ða ðus cwæð: “Hwi ðu me sceððest?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Da che fatto fu poi di sangue bruno, 35 ricominciò a dir: «Perché mi scerpi? 36 non hai tu spirto di pietade alcuno?
37 Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi: 38 ben dovrebb’ esser la tua man più pia, 39 se state fossimo anime di serpi».
query.result:
**English:**
34 When he was then made red with blood, 35 he began to say again: "Why do you tear me? 36 Do you have no spirit of pity?
37 We were men, and now we are made into stumps: 38 your hand should be more merciful, 39 even if we had been the souls of serpents."
**Old English:**
34 Þa he geworðen wæs on blode brun, 35 eft ongeat he ða sprecan and cwæð: "Hwæt me sceððeð ge? 36 næbbe ge nanre miltsan gast?
37 Weras we wæron, and nu syndon we geworden stoccas: 38 wel sceolde ðin hand milde beon, 39 ðeah we nædran wæron."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Come d’un stizzo verde ch’arso sia 41 da l’un de’ capi, che da l’altro geme 42 e cigola per vento che va via,
43 sì de la scheggia rotta usciva insieme 44 parole e sangue; ond’ io lasciai la cima 45 cadere, e stetti come l’uom che teme.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Like from a green stick that is burning 41 at one end, and at the other drips 42 and hisses with the wind that escapes,
43 so from the broken splinter came together 44 words and blood; whereupon I let fall 45 the tip, and stood like a man who is afraid.
**Old English:**
40 Swa swa of grene treowe ðæt byrnð 41 æt ðam anum ende, and æt ðam oðrum wepeð 42 and hweteð for ðam winde ðe ðærut gæð,
43 swa of ðam brocenan sceolde togædere 44 word and blod; ða ic ða wrixle forlet 45 feallan, and stod swa swa se ðe forht bið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 «S’elli avesse potuto creder prima», 47 rispuose ’l savio mio, «anima lesa, 48 ciò c’ha veduto pur con la mia rima,
49 non averebbe in te la man distesa; 50 ma la cosa incredibile mi fece 51 indurlo ad ovra ch’a me stesso pesa.
query.result:
**English:**
46 "If he could have believed before," 47 my wise guide replied, "wretched soul, 48 what he has seen even in my rhyme,
49 he would not have stretched out his hand against you; 50 but the incredible thing made me 51 harden him to an action that weighs on me."
**Old English:**
46 "Gif he hæfde mæg geliðan ær," 47 andswarode min wisa lareow, "wædla sawl, 48 ðæt ðe he geseah ðurh mine ræda,
49 ne hæfde he on ðe hond astreht; 50 ac ðæt ungeleaffulle me geworhte 51 ðæt ic hine herde on ða weorc ðe me is wrað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Ma dilli chi tu fosti, sì che ’n vece 53 d’alcun’ ammenda tua fama rinfreschi 54 nel mondo sù, dove tornar li lece».
query.result:
**English:**
52 But tell me who you were, so that in place 53 of some amends your fame may be refreshed 54 in the world above, where it is permitted to return.
**Old English:**
52 Ac sege me ðu hwæt ðu wære, ðæt ðin lof 53 on worulde eft wunige ðurh ðone æfterne dom, 54 ðær ðu nu eardfæst ealle gewunadest.
Please note that line 54 is a bit more difficult to translate literally, as the Old English word "gewunadest" has a range of meanings, including "to dwell," "to inhabit," and "to be accustomed to." I have chosen the translation "to be accustomed to" here, as it best fits the context of the passage.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 E ’l tronco: «Sì col dolce dir m’adeschi, 56 ch’i’ non posso tacere; e voi non gravi 57 perch’ ïo un poco a ragionar m’inveschi.
query.result:
**English:**
55 And the trunk: "You entice me so with your sweet speech, 56 that I cannot be silent; and do not be offended 57 if I indulge myself a little in conversation.
**Old English:**
55 And ðæt treow: "Þus ðu mid ðinum swetan wordum me tælst, 56 ðæt ic ne mæg ðurh ðæt ðigian; and ne beo ðe ðæs lað 57 ðæt ic me lyt ðurh ðæt on spræce besette."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Io son colui che tenni ambo le chiavi 59 del cor di Federigo, e che le volsi, 60 serrando e diserrando, sì soavi,
61 che dal secreto suo quasi ogn’ uom tolsi; 62 fede portai al glorïoso offizio, 63 tanto ch’i’ ne perde’ li sonni e ’ polsi.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I am the one who held both keys 59 of Frederick's heart, and who turned them, 60 locking and unlocking, so gently,
61 that I kept almost everyone out of his secrets; 62 I was faithful to my glorious office, 63 so much so that I lost sleep and strength because of it.
**Old English:**
58 Ic eom se ðe heold ba ða cægðu 59 Federices heortan, and ða wende, 60 tybende and untybende, swa softe,
61 ðæt ic fram his digolnesse neanigne mon næfre ne alædde; 62 treowe ic wæs ðam mæran mæðle, 63 swa ðæt ic ðærfor forleas and slæp and reste.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 La meretrice che mai da l’ospizio 65 di Cesare non torse li occhi putti, 66 morte comune e de le corti vizio,
67 infiammò contra me li animi tutti; 68 e li ’nfiammati infiammar sì Augusto, 69 che ’ lieti onor tornaro in tristi lutti.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The harlot who never turned her wanton eyes 65 from Caesar's court, 66 the common death and vice of courts,
67 inflamed all hearts against me; 68 and the inflamed ones so inflamed Augustus, 69 that my joyful honors turned to sorrowful mourning.
**Old English:**
64 Sē myltystre ðē næfre of ðǣm gestsele 65 Cēseres ne awende hire wuldran ēagan, 66 gemæne dēað and ðāra healla unþēaw,
67 ontende ongean mē ðā mōd ealle; 68 and ðā ontendan swā ontendon Augustus, 69 ðæt ðā glædan wuldor gewendon on sārige hreowe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 L’animo mio, per disdegnoso gusto, 71 credendo col morir fuggir disdegno, 72 ingiusto fece me contra me giusto.
query.result:
**English:**
70 My soul, out of disdainful pride, 71 believing that by dying it could escape disdain, 72 unjustly made me, who was just, act against myself.
**Old English:**
70 Min mod, for unrihtes lust, 71 wende ðurh ðone deað ðæt unriht afleon, 72 and ðurh ðone unriht ðone riht forleas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Per le nove radici d’esto legno 74 vi giuro che già mai non ruppi fede 75 al mio segnor, che fu d’onor sì degno.
query.result:
**English:**
73 By the nine roots of this tree 74 I swear that I never broke faith 75 with my lord, who was so worthy of honor.
**Old English:**
73 Be ðam nigon ðinga ðæs treowes 74 ic ðe secge ðæt næfre ic ne bræc geleafan 75 minum hlaforde, ðe wæs ðæs wurðmyntes weorð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 E se di voi alcun nel mondo riede, 77 conforti la memoria mia, che giace 78 ancor del colpo che ’nvidia le diede».
query.result:
**English:**
76 And if any of you return to the world, 77 comfort my memory, which lies 78 still from the blow that envy dealt it.
**Old English:**
76 And gif hwa ðara eft cymeð on foldan, 77 ðonne gefrætwiað minne gemynd, ðe ðær gyt ligeð 78 ðurh ðæs leanes slæge ðe him ða laðe gesceodon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Un poco attese, e poi «Da ch’el si tace», 80 disse ’l poeta a me, «non perder l’ora; 81 ma parla, e chiedi a lui, se più ti piace».
query.result:
**English:**
79 He waited a little, and then, “Since he is silent,” 80 the poet said to me, “do not waste the time; 81 but speak, and ask him, if it pleases you more.”
**Old English:**
79 He bád ða lyt, and ða he cwæð to me, 80 “Nu he geswogen hæfð, ne forleós ðu ða tíd; 81 ac sprec nu to him, gif ðe selre þynceð.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Ond’ ïo a lui: «Domandal tu ancora 83 di quel che credi ch’a me satisfaccia; 84 ch’i’ non potrei, tanta pietà m’accora».
query.result:
**English:**
82 And I to him: "Ask me again 83 about what you think would satisfy me; 84 for I could not, so much pity overwhelms me."
**Old English:**
82 And ic ða to him: "Frina ðu ða gyt 83 ymbe ðæt ðe ðu wene ðæt me geðuhte; 84 forðam ic ne mæg, swa micel me sar geðreateð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Perciò ricominciò: «Se l’om ti faccia 86 liberamente ciò che ’l tuo dir priega, 87 spirito incarcerato, ancor ti piaccia
88 di dirne come l’anima si lega 89 in questi nocchi; e dinne, se tu puoi, 90 s’alcuna mai di tai membra si spiega».
query.result:
**English:**
85 Therefore he began again: "If a man 86 freely does for you what your speech entreats, 87 imprisoned spirit, may it still please you
88 to tell us how the soul is bound 89 in these knots; and tell us, if you can, 90 if any ever extricates itself from such members."
**Old English:**
85 Þærfore eft he ongan: "Gif ðe mon gefylle 86 freolice ðæt ðin word biddeð, 87 gast gebunden, ðe ðeah gyt lyfað
88 to secganne hu ðæt sawl gewiteð 89 on ðas hleotan; and secge ðu, gif ðu meaht, 90 hwæðer ænig ðara ðissa lima æfre gewiteð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Allor soffiò il tronco forte, e poi 92 si convertì quel vento in cotal voce: 93 «Brievemente sarà risposto a voi.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Then the trunk blew strongly, and then 92 that wind became a voice, saying: 93 "Briefly will it be answered to you.
**Old English:**
91 Þa bleow ðæs wudu blæd swiðe strong, and ða 92 wearð se wind to wope swilcre stefne: 93 "Sceortlice sceal beon andsware gegolden."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Quando si parte l’anima feroce 95 dal corpo ond’ ella stessa s’è disvelta, 96 Minòs la manda a la settima foce.
query.result:
**English:**
94 When the fierce soul departs 95 from the body from which it has torn itself, 96 Minos sends it to the seventh abyss.
**Old English:**
94 Þonne se wælhreowa gæst gewíteð 95 of ðam líce þe heo ær of gewât, 96 Minos híe on ða seofoðan sendeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Cade in la selva, e non l’è parte scelta; 98 ma là dove fortuna la balestra, 99 quivi germoglia come gran di spelta.
query.result:
**English:**
97 He falls in the forest, and no place is chosen for him; 98 but wherever fortune hurls him, 99 there he sprouts like a grain of spelt.
**Old English:**
97 He fylð on ðone wudu, and him nænig stede ne geceas, 98 ac ðær hine wyrd bescyt, 99 ðær he ðonne gryt swa speltes sæd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Surge in vermena e in pianta silvestra: 101 l’Arpie, pascendo poi de le sue foglie, 102 fanno dolore, e al dolor fenestra.
query.result:
**English:**
100 It sprouts into a twig and a wild plant: 101 the Harpies, feeding then on its leaves, 102 cause pain, and to the pain a window.
**Old English:**
100 Hit wyxð on telgum and on wudu wilde: 101 ða Harpias, etende ða ða leaf, 102 doð ðær sorge, and ðære sorge ðurhgang.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Come l’altre verrem per nostre spoglie, 104 ma non però ch’alcuna sen rivesta, 105 ché non è giusto aver ciò ch’om si toglie.
query.result:
**English:**
103 As the others will come for our spoils, 104 but not so that any one of them will be reclothed with them, 105 for it is not right to have that which one takes away.
**Old English:**
103 Swa ða oðre cumað for urum reafum, 104 ac na ðeah ðe ænig him on wende, 105 forðæm hit nis riht ðæt mon hæbbe ðæt he him ðær ætbregð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Qui le strascineremo, e per la mesta 107 selva saranno i nostri corpi appesi, 108 ciascuno al prun de l’ombra sua molesta».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Here we will drag them, and through the sad 107 wood our bodies will be hung, 108 each one on the thorn of his own painful shade."
**Old English:**
106 Her we sceolon hig dragan, and ðurh ða dimman 107 wudu beoð ure lichoman ahangen, 108 æghwylc æt ðam þorne his agenre geswencednysse."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Noi eravamo ancora al tronco attesi, 110 credendo ch’altro ne volesse dire, 111 quando noi fummo d’un romor sorpresi,
112 similemente a colui che venire 113 sente ’l porco e la caccia a la sua posta, 114 ch’ode le bestie, e le frasche stormire.
query.result:
**English:**
109 We were still waiting at the trunk, 110 believing that he wanted to say something else to us, 111 when we were surprised by a noise,
112 similar to that which someone hears 113 when he senses the boar and the hunt coming to his position, 114 and he hears the beasts and the rustling of the branches.
**Old English:**
109 We wæron ða giet ðær on ðam stocce, 110 wendon ðæt he wolde us hwæt secgan, 111 ða we wurdon of ðam hreame ofwondered,
112 gelice ðam ðe ðone earhswín gehyreð 113 and ða huntan ðe hine willað ofslihan, 114 ðe ða deor gehyreð and ða dúne stirgan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Ed ecco due da la sinistra costa, 116 nudi e graffiati, fuggendo sì forte, 117 che de la selva rompieno ogne rosta.
query.result:
**English:**
115 And behold, two on the left flank, 116 naked and scratched, fleeing so swiftly 117 that they broke every branch of the forest.
**Old English:**
115 And ða ic geseah twegen on ðære wynstran healfe, 116 nacode and forwundode, fleonde swiðe hrade, 117 ðæt ða wudurofenas wæron ealle tobrosnode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Quel dinanzi: «Or accorri, accorri, morte!». 119 E l’altro, cui pareva tardar troppo, 120 gridava: «Lano, sì non furo accorte
121 le gambe tue a le giostre dal Toppo!».
query.result:
**English:**
118 The one in front: "Now run, run, death!". 119 And the other, who seemed to be taking too long, 120 shouted: "Lano, your legs were not so nimble
121 at the joust by the Toppo!".
**Old English:**
118 Se ðe forma: "Nu ðu hrade ðu hrade ðe deað!". 119 And ðæs oðres ðe ðuhte ðæt hit wære to langsum, 120 he cleopode: "Lano, ðine sceancan næron swa snelle
121 on ðæm plegan æt ðæm Toppe!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
122 E poi che forse li fallia la lena, 123 di sé e d’un cespuglio fece un groppo.
124 Di rietro a loro era la selva piena 125 di nere cagne, bramose e correnti 126 come veltri ch’uscisser di catena.
query.result:
**English:**
122 And then, perhaps because his strength was failing him, 123 he made a knot of himself and a bush.
124 Behind them, the wood was full 125 of black hounds, ravenous and running 126 like greyhounds unleashed from a leash.
**Old English:**
122 And ða ða him mihte mægenalican, 123 he geworhte of himsylfum and ðæs wudu wyrtruman.
124 Æfter him wæs ða wudu ful 125 swartra hara, hungrigra and hreðra, 126 swa ða hundas ðe of bende brecað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 In quel che s’appiattò miser li denti, 128 e quel dilaceraro a brano a brano; 129 poi sen portar quelle membra dolenti.
query.result:
**English:**
127 He in whom the wretch sank his teeth, 128 and tore him limb from limb; 129 then he carried off those suffering members.
**Old English:**
127 He on ðæm ðe ða earman his teð gefæstnode, 128 and ðone tobræc lim from lime; 129 ða ða dolglican leomu he ðanon bær.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Presemi allor la mia scorta per mano, 131 e menommi al cespuglio che piangea 132 per le rotture sanguinenti in vano.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Then my guide took me by the hand, 131 and led me to the bush that wept 132 in vain for its bloody wounds.
**Old English:**
130 ða genam min latteow mec be ðære handa, 131 and lædde mec to ðam bremele ðe weop 132 on ydel for ðam blodigan bite.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 «O Iacopo», dicea, «da Santo Andrea, 134 che t’è giovato di me fare schermo? 135 che colpa ho io de la tua vita rea?».
query.result:
**English:**
133 "O James," he said, "from Saint Andrew, 134 what good did it do you to shield me? 135 What fault of mine led to your wicked life?"
**Old English:**
133 "Eala Iacobe," cwæð he, "of Sancte Andrea, 134 hwæt fremede hit ðe ðæt ðu me scylde? 135 Hwæt hæbbe ic agylt ðinre yflan life?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Quando ’l maestro fu sovr’ esso fermo, 137 disse: «Chi fosti, che per tante punte 138 soffi con sangue doloroso sermo?».
query.result:
**English:**
136 When the master was standing over him, 137 he said: "Who were you, that through so many wounds 138 endured painful speech with blood?".
**Old English:**
136 Þa se mæster ofer ðone fæstan stod, 137 cwæð: "Hwa wære ðu, ðe ðurh swa fela wunda 138 blodigne sermone sorhlice spræce?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Ed elli a noi: «O anime che giunte 140 siete a veder lo strazio disonesto 141 c’ha le mie fronde sì da me disgiunte,
142 raccoglietele al piè del tristo cesto.
query.result:
**English:**
139 And he said to us: "O souls who have come 140 to see the shameful devastation 141 that has so separated my branches from me,
142 gather them at the foot of the sad bush.
**Old English:**
139 And he sæde to us: "Eala, ða sawla ðe cumað 140 to geseonne ðone unarwurðan toslitnysse 141 ðe hæfð mine leafu swa fram me atogen,
142 gegaderiað hi æt ðæs woestan treowes fótum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
143 I’ fui de la città che nel Batista 144 mutò ’l primo padrone; ond’ ei per questo
145 sempre con l’arte sua la farà trista; 146 e se non fosse che ’n sul passo d’Arno 147 rimane ancor di lui alcuna vista,
148 que’ cittadin che poi la rifondarno 149 sovra ’l cener che d’Attila rimase, 150 avrebber fatto lavorare indarno.
query.result:
**English:**
143 I was from the city that John the Baptist 144 changed its first patron; because of this
145 he will always make it sad with his art; 146 and if it were not that at the ford of the Arno 147 there still remains some sight of him,
148 those citizens who later refounded it 149 on the ashes that remained from Attila, 150 would have labored in vain.
**Old English:**
143 Ic wæs of ðære ceastre ðe on ðam Fulluhtere 144 awende ðone ærestan hlaford; for ðam he ðurh ðis
145 symle mid his cræfte ða geunrotsað; 146 and gif hit nære ðæt æt ðæs Arn þære ea 147 ðær wunað gyt of him sum gesyhð,
148 ða burgware ðe ða eft ða getimbredon 149 ofer ða ascan ðe of Attalan belaf, 150 hi hæfdon gewunnen on idel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 Io fei gibetto a me de le mie case».
query.result:
**English:**
151 I made a gallows for myself out of my houses.
**Old English:**
151 Ic worhte gealga of minum husum.
